resources.string: Talkback Tutorial
Lessons
This module covers how to adjust TalkBack\'s reading controls, which lets us make TalkBack read and navigate in different ways. When you change modes, TalkBack will speak the mode you switched to.
To change your mode, swipe up and down in one motion. Try to go through all of the options before moving on.
You can go backwards through the list. Swipe down then up in one motion to go through the list in the opposite direction.
Modes can also be switched by swiping with three fingers horizontally either to the left or to the right. Try going through the list with three finger swipes in both directions before moving on.
That\'s all there is to changing modes. The rest of this lesson covers how to use these modes. Activate the button below to finish this module.
Finish module
The \"Controls\" reading mode allows jumping between buttons, sliders, switches, and other interactive things.
Switch to the %s reading mode and swipe down to jump to the next %s.
You performed the wrong action. Please try again.
This element will push you back

There are reading and navigation modes. Reading modes help you read in a granular way, such as by words, paragraphs, or characters. Navigation modes help you move around more efficiently, such as by jumping from button to button.
Finish Module
Can you can a canned can into an un-canned can like a canner can can a canned can into an un-canned can?
She sells seashells on the seashore. The shells she sells are seashells, I’m sure. And if she sells seashells on the seashore, Then I’m sure she sells seashore shells.
Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers; A peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked; If Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers, Where’s the peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked
There\'s another %s below. Jump to it.
This is the last %s. Activate it to continue.
To continue, swipe up to the previous %s
That\'s the basics of jumping between %s. Activate to %s.
header
headers
control
controls
link
links
continue
finish module
The \"Headers\" reading mode allows you to jump between headers, such those found before blocks of text or groups of form fields.
The \"Links\" navigation mode lets you jump between clickable links on a page, such as a URL.
We will now learn to use each reading modes. As you have learned previously, please switch to the reading mode that says \"Paragraph\"

You will now learn to transition between paragraphs. A single swipe up or down will transition between different paragraphs that are on the screen. Please try it until you reach a button that says finish lesson, then double tap to finish the lesson. For your information, this will be a very long practice text so it would be easier to complete it using the Paragraph reading mode. However, you can still try out different reading modes such as Characters, Words and lines reading modes.

You have completed the lesson. To summarise, in this lesson you have learnt to use the Paragraph reading mode to navigate through the page. In the future, you can utilise these different reading modes such as Headers, Controls, Links and more, to navigate through your phone. Sending you back to the Lesson modules.
If you have changed reading mode to Paragraph mode, Please double tap to continue
End of Lesson Challenge

A castle that will bring hours of magical play and fun to your little one. It will encourage young children to use their creative thoughts and develop their minds. Decorated with beautiful mushrooms and features a fairy gate that opens and closes. It will help children discover new things about themselves and their world every day.

Welcome to Lesson 2\'s challenge. In challenges, you\'ll be presented with practical scenarios to demonstrate your new learnt skills. In this challenge, you\'ll be presented with a store. To complete the lesson, add the tennis ball and the tennis racquet to your watchlist. The tennis ball has a price of $5, and the tennis racquet has a price of $180. You may now start.
You have completed the challenge. Sending you to the main menu.

In this challenge, you\'ll be presented an article with an embedded video already playing. To complete the challenge, pause the video, and return its slider to the beginning of the video, then replay it. You may now start.
Embedded Video
The Different Memory Storage Areas of the Brain
Saturday 15th July, 2042
Author: Billy Eggman

Within the cerebral cortex, the frontal and temporal lobes are heavily involved in explicit/declarative memory processes. Episodic memories tent to be stored in the frontal lobe (particularly the pre-frontal cortex) and temporal lobe. The same can be assumed with semantic memories. Components of our memories such as visuals and sounds are stored in areas throughout the cerebral cortex. Sound is sotred in the temporal lobe, while visuals in the occipital lobe.

The hippocampus (in temporal lobe) consolidates memories, turning short term memories into long term declarative memories; semantic and episodic. It also has roles in emotional memory due to its proximity to the amygdala, and spatial memory.

The amygdala (in temporal lobe) is involved in emotional memory, and links emotions and emotional responses (such as fear and aggression) to declarative memories. This helps us remember experiences by the emotion we felt during its formation. Also involved in the formation of procedural memories.

The cerebellum is involved in motor learning and the memory of conditioned reflexes. It\'s involved in implicit memory such as procedural memories that require movement. Also has a role in spatial navigation.
Finally, language is stored in Broca’s area in the left frontal lobe, and memory for pictures are stored in the occipital lobe.
